noun.description: The devoicing of a consonant; specifically (in Celtic languages) the change over a period of time of voiced consonants to the corresponding voiceless consonants (e.g. of g, d, b, v to k, t, p, f) under the influence of another consonant.
The transposition of the final letter of a word to the beginning of the word that follows. Compare "metanalysis"rare.

origin: Mid 17th century (in an earlier sense). From post-classical Latin provection-, provectio action of advancing or going forward, preferment from classical Latin prōvect-, past participial stem of prōvehere + -iō. Compare Middle French provection action of advancing.
